ATTN AMSA High School Students! We have an amazing oppty for you to participate in a Harvard pilot course on Strategies to Improve Productivity and Study Skills.

It will be held live online this Friday (8/28/20) at 5:30 PM EST. If you are interested in attending, check your email for instructions. You must respond by Thursday, 6:00 PM EST.

Virtual seats are limited and will be assigned on a first come, first serve basis.

Below are some of the questions that will be addressed during the session:
- Why do over 50% of high performing high school students underperform in college?
- Why don’t I always do what I plan to do?
- Is willpower a limited resource?
- How can I overcome procrastination?
- Why shouldn't time management be my priority?
- Why don’t many students stick to a goal or aspiration?
- How can I multi-task best?
- What is the most important study skill?
- What is one of the best ways to study?

Have you had your summer plans canceled? Need something to do over the summer? Interested in coding? Then join the AMSA Coding Competitions, running every Saturday from 2-3:30 pm, beginning June 27th.

These online competitions will be occurring on HackerRank and will test AMSA students of all ages and abilities on their programming speed and accuracy in their coding language of choice. Moderated by qualified AMSA students, this is a great opportunity for anyone who would like to test and improve upon their current computer science skills, and do something beneficial over the summer. This is also open for those with little experience, who want to learn more. Beyond this, various prizes will be awarded weekly to the top competitors.

For those interested, fill out this form: https://forms.gle/2wjGNCRV3GjrsMS58
For other questions/more information, email amsacoding@gmail.com.

She was chosen for her orchestration of the diverse book drive with the Black Student Union. This video is her summary of the project during the virtual ceremony this week.

Oluchi posted about the book drive in December:
“The Black Student Union's Blizzard Book Drive for representation has come to a close, and we are very thankful for all the contributions! We received 46 children’s books representing several ethnic minority groups. We are so grateful to be able to give back to a community of children, opening their minds to endless possibilities. Representation is so important in books and media! Thank you again to all the students, parents, and staff who donated! Happy Holidays!”

We are proud and excited to announce that four AMSA students are recipients of the 2020 Award for Aspirations in Computing from the NCWIT Aspirations in Computing.

Award recipients are selected based on their aptitude and aspirations in technology and computing, as demonstrated by their computing experience, computing-related activities, leadership experience, tenacity in the face of barriers to access, and plans for post-secondary education.

This year’s awardees from AMSA, all seniors, are:
> Inbar Artzi, National Certificate of Distinction
> Olivia Deckers, Affiliate Winner
> Grace Menzie, National Certificate of Distinction
> Erika Meredith, Affiliate Honorable Mention

"Congratulations to each of these students,” said AMSA computer science teacher Ms. Bandaru, who endorsed them for the award. “Algorithms and computational thinking are an integral part of AMSA’s curriculum and valuable to students’ future success in any field.”

NCWIT is holding a national virtual awards ceremony on Saturday, May 30, for all awardees.
#ncwitaic

We know the tournament is going to be different and not exactly what we envisioned- but we’re still planning a super fun filled day! Please register at www.amsacs.org/golf. If you have questions, please contact us at amsagolf@gmail.com.

We are proud to announce that eighth grader Manu (Nick) Prabakaran earned 2nd Place in the annual National History Day Massachusetts competition in the Research Paper category for his age group!

And now it is on to Nationals! Nick’s paper, “The Past Building the Future: The Barriers Breached during the Hong Kong Handover and how it Builds Our Current World,” advances to the National History Day competition, which will be held virtually in June.

“I'm very proud of him. He has the heart of a true scholar. It's not the grade but the knowledge that is his goal,” said Nick’s history teacher, Mr. Anderson.

Congratulations and best of luck to Nick!

From @amsastudentgovernment... Hello AMSA community, here is our first Tutorial Tuesday of quarantine! If you make your own pizza be sure to send us a picture or video. Also, if you are interested in submitting your own tutorial DM us!

Ingredients:
- Frozen pizza dough
- Flour as needed
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1/2 cup pizza sauce
- 2 1/2 cups mozzarella cheese

Instructions:
- Set dough aside to defrost.
- Once the dough is defrosted, spread flour on your counter to prevent sticking and roll out dough.
- Once the pizza dough is rolled to its desired shape, transfer it to your pan.
- Spread the olive oil on the dough, then the pizza sauce.
- Sprinkle the mozzarella cheese over the sauce.
- Add any other desired toppings, including Parmesan cheese on the crust.
- Follow the frozen dough’s oven instructions.

Another AMSA student who is giving back to the community during these trying times is senior Madelyn Bedard. Three times a week Maddie has been picking up work clothes for staff in the ER at Clinton Hospital, sanitizing them at a laundering facility, and returning them to the hospital. Many staff who work long shifts with COVID-19 positive patients are concerned about bringing work clothes home and infecting their own families. Especially since most home washing machines do not heat water hot enough to kill all bacteria and viruses. Maddie’s act of kindness has been greatly appreciated by the ER staff and has helped to ease the worry for many people! We should note that she performs this community service safely with complete proper protection and guidance from her mother, who is an RN in the ER at Clinton Hospital.

Congratulations to these 8th graders who came out on top in a live presentation competition last week! The “Innovation Challenge” tasked student teams from across the U.S. to develop a new health science or medical innovation. Led by Mr. Gordon, the AMSA group developed and presented a concept for a phone app to help kids manage asthma. Student judges from other schools watched the presentation live online and gave it the top score among 4-5 student teams that presented.

“Our kids did great! They were prepared, brief, and to the point. They clearly presented the purpose of our app,” said Mr. Gordon.

The 14-student AMSA team came up with the idea together, then they split into two groups: One group designed the logo and made a video demonstration of the product, while the other group designed the slides and presented the idea live.

The “Innovation Challenge” concluded a five-week Adventures in Health Science and Medicine program, in which AMSA students joined other schools across the country online for hands-on activities and collaborative discussions.

Senior captain Diana Bibinski scored 11 points while junior captain Anna Ciolino added nine but it wasn't enough as the fifth-seeded Girls Varsity Basketball team fell to top-seeded Maynard, 46-31, in an MIAA Division 4 Central Semifinal at WPI on Wednesday night.

AMSA was arguably the better team in the first half, wreaking havoc on the defensive end, but offense was tough to come by all night. The Eagles trailed the Tigers 14-9 at the half.

In the second half, Maynard's star senior and the third leading scorer in all of Central Mass, scored 15 of her game-high 24 points and the Tigers would pull away for a 15-point win.

The memorable run for the Eagles - who finish 2019-20 at 17-6 - marks the first time an AMSA basketball team advanced to a sectional semifinal. Maynard improves to 18-4 and will face No. 3 Blackstone Valley Tech in the District Finals on Saturday morning at 10:30 a.m. back at WPI.
